We made 7ft guitars the had a ladder of RBG LEDs up the neck. The bass guitar was the brawn in which we made a high striker carnival game with a drum pad and a mallet to strike it with. description.text:
https://www.youtube.com/embed/0AjhUg5aQ2E

This is the Swiss Army Knife of imaging, the unit is more capable than a standard camera because the unit has access to 4 separate imagers, 3 of which can be filtered. The 4th imager is a FLIR lepton camera for thermal imaging. Not only can the device be used for multispectral imaging, the cluster of cameras forms a synthetic aperture which allows for the ability to see a target around occlusions. The potential for this unit is endless and the fact that it can be 3D printed and assembled using readily available and cheap parts allows otherwise expensive technology into the hands of the layman.

All components can be manufactured on a Makerbot. Preferably using ABS plastic. All components are screwed together using #6-32 screws. For more information please refer to: https://hackaday.io/project/6730-synthetic-aperture-multispectral-imager

The design process was long! If there are any questions, don't hesitate to leave a comment!

comments.text: This is a really neat project, thanks for posting. Are the RasPi cameras sensitive to UV, or do you have a different camera for that part? I am assuming the NIR image is from one of the RasPi cameras with the IR filter removed, the NoIR or something?
comments.author: kovo

comments.text: Thank you for taking the time to comment! The raspberry pi cameras are sensitive to UV light. Only two types of cameras were utilized for this project: The FLIR lepton and the raspberry pi NoIR development camera.

Put your droid razr HD on the phone mount and you can slide it from left to right while mounted!  
ENJOY

I taken tetrahedron which is pyramide with triangular sides. Then I connected 2 of them in one figure in meshmix. Printing in one set is a quite nice challenge. Need support below 20 degrees and a good brim, because the reversed pyramide touches the base only a few millimeters and it is hard to print in stabilizing.

But put them standing it is a real challenge!
You see on photo, how I printed. Set support for less than 20 degrees to keep the reversed pyramide stable

To mount the servos you can use #6-32 x 1-1/2" machine screws, these can be found at Home Depot for like a $1.18 for 6 screws with nuts included. Ive only personally printed the bracket for two 1/4" threaded rods, and modified it for the remaining brackets. This being said, I haven't personally tested the 3 other mounts, and would appreciate it if you could let me know if those worked well or if I need to make modifications. Print at 25.4 scale if using a printer based in mm, as I designed these mounts in inches. The bottom mounted brackets have a thicker bottom with with recessed holes so you can mount it to a flat surface without any problems.

Print at 25.4 scale if your printer uses mm as I designed the part in inches. Use #6-32 x 1-1/2" screws to attach the servo, these can be purchased at Home Depot for about a dollar fifty for 6 nuts and bolts. Use 1/4 inch threaded rods for the REV1 version, the others can be mounted with various other types of screws. I printed mine in PLA, so you may experience some ABS shrinkage, but with some trial and error you should be able to scale it to compensate for that. If you do print in ABS and find the right scale to print at to fight the ABS shrinkage, please comment the scale so I can update the instructions. Lay the part however it will print best for YOUR printer, try letting the side with the most surface area be the side that is laying flat. These take anywhere from 45 minutes to 2 hours to print depending on your speed settings with .2mm layer thickness.
This is the first thing I have printed from scratch drew it up in FreeCad. To hold 2 fishing rods under a shelf that goes across the top of a sliding door.

author: arod24

description.text: This is a mounting bracket for the HC-SR04 sonar range finder. This bracket is designed to have the rangefinder snap into place and protect the sensor from shorts. The bracket has two mounting holes the perfect size for #6-32 screws, although the size of the holes can be enlarged considerably with a drill. I designed the part in inches with the intention to scale the part by 25.4, but have found that if you scale it by 26 you have the best results. To protect your rangefinder further, I made sure there was enough space to insert a piece of a foam paper plate cut to size to help with vibration. The bracket completely covers the back of the rangefinder, allowing you to mount it directly onto metal without having to worry about shorts. Tips are welcome! I am a college student and every dollar goes a long way in furthering my education.

I used a Prusa i3 with PLA filament at a .2mm layer height and it printed in around 30 minutes. The sensor easily snaps in the bracket without the need of screws. If you cut a piece of a foam paper plate to put behind the sensor it helps considerably with vibration if you are using this with a robot. Scale the part by 26 if you use PLA and slightly more if you are using ABS.

comments.text: I had a project where I needed to mount a whole bunch of HY-SRF05 ultrasonic sensors. The mounting holes provided are worthless for that purpose and thus the search for another solution. This turned out to be just the ticket -- though I had to make a small modification to account for the fact that the HY-SRF05 has 5 pins instead of 4. Easy enough to open up the gap by another tenth of an inch. The first one printed was in PLA just to see if it would suit. I printed several in ABS -- had to scale it up to account for the greater shrinkage of ABS but it worked great. The balance were printed in PETG. PETG is more flexible -- which is an advantage when popping the sensors in and out. Anyway, this design was just the thing for my needs. Thanks!

Designed this for my roomate, whom is the most savage (If you don't understand what savage means in this instance, look it up in the urban dictionary). I printed it at 25.4 scale because I designed the part in inches, but scale it however large you want it. Looks great if you print the back part that holds up the letters a darker color and the last few layers on top a lighter color, it really makes the letters pop. Simply pause the print and switch the colors once you notice it stops printing the supports. Great gift for a friend or sibling. When I gave it to my roommate he loved it, enough said.

I printed mine at 25.4 scale, although you can print larger or smaller depending on your preferences and what your printer can handle. to make the word pop out from the supports, try switching filament colors mid-print once it has stopped printing the supports. Works best if you print it flat on its back, you will have no overhang that way.

title: Yuneec Q500 External Camera Cable Mounting Bracket

description.text:
This is a Bracket to mount the External Antenna Wire after the CGO2 has been modified with a 30 cm Ufl to RP-SMA Antenna Wire this Wire will come from the Camera to the rear of the Yuneec Q500 Drone.

How to install:

This Bracket should be epoxied to the bottom of your Q500 and also has a optional pilot Hole to add a screw for an additional way to secure the Bracket to your Q500.

Printed in ABS at 80% Infill.

1 x Tube Plastic Epoxy
1 x 30 cm Ufl to RP-SMA Antenna Adapter Cable
1 x 2.4 GHz Cloverleaf Polarized Antenna
1 x #8 1/2" Screw (Optional)

title: Z Motor Stand-off for FolgerTech 2020 i3

description.text:
UPDATE:
Re-uploaded the STL files with units in mm.

Standoff for Z motor on Folgertech's 2020 i3. This can free up around 40mm Z build height originally taken by the Z motor shaft and coupler. I designed this for an 8 mm leadscrew constrained with a 608 bearing at the top, however, stock m5 rod supplied with the kit should work just fine with or without the 608 bearing.

If used with 608 bearing, the coupler doubles as a collar.

z_motor_mounts.stl requires around 65mm m3 bolt. Rev2 eliminates this but needs 4 additional m3 bolts and nuts.

comments.text: This has been a great mod for my Folgertech 2020, allowing a much needed increase in Z volume. However, I advise not using the bearings. The bearings eliminate the flexibility in the coupler, and overconstrains the lead screws. This introduce Z-wobble, causing Z-banding in the prints. I had this problem in my prints, and the Z-banding went away after removing the bearings.
comments.author: elkayem

comments.text: Just about to print these and was wondering why you'd have a bearing to constrain the movement of the coupler?  Isn't the point of the flexible coupler to account for alignment issues and possibly rods that aren't straight?
comments.author: boffthingiverse

comments.text: Printed these yesterday and went to install them tonight.  Noticed an issue with the design as soon as I went to bolt them up.  Only one of the four corners has a recess for the screw head on the upper part of the rev2 design that I printed.  The other 3 corners have a sloped surface that the bolt head wants to tighten against but can't really do so effectively since it's sloped.  Even worse for me it adds an extra couple of mm that makes the difference between 10mm bolts working 16mm bolts.  I have lots of 10mm on hand...but only 1 16mm.  So I've got an extra trip to the hardware store now before I can get my printer back together.
comments.author: jhitesma

comments.text: Just noticed this myself. Already 1/3 of the way through the print so I'll make due somehow. Should be fixed though.
comments.author: jhitesma

comments.text: Heartless made a new remix with the holes all properly countersunk...but if you're 1/3rd through printing a bit of xacto work is probably your best bet :D
comments.author: onesun43

comments.text: New updates work great! Printed and mounted these yesterday. Now I get 165mm Z height wooo! I used M3x20mm for the bottom(bracket) and original screws for the top(motor).

comments.text: I used the original motor screws for the top. Then 16mm m3 bolts and nuts. at the bottom.

comments.text: Just tried the original motor screws that came with my kit...and they aren't long enough for the top :(  They work on the one hole that has the countersunk recess, but not on the other 3 corners.  Maybe Folger is shipping shorter bolts now?  These are 12mm long that came in mine and don't reach.

The belt tensioner was derived from heartless's design: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:872944 modified slightly to fit this idler.

This is a case for the Kimdrox Adjustable Voltage Regulator found on amazon. It will likely work for all the other brand voltage regulators of similar design found around the web. The board has 2mm clearance under it. Its difficult to see in the pictures but there are built in standoffs in the corners and the pins fit in the PCB holes. The lid will need a bit of carving to fit.

I included the 123D file as well.

If you are looking for a more complex design check out http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:942939

The voltage regulator can be found here:

http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00L6VSXEC?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00&pldnSite=1
The lid will need three notches carved in the lid to fit. An exacto knife will do this nicely.

This is a mold to help make a sand castle in the shape of an empire state building.

Made this model using all geometric shapes from Tinkercad. This project was inspired by the Thingiversity Math Challenge: Build A Castle challenge.

There are three different files:
empire_sand_castle_15cm.stl is the 15 cm tall model
empire_sand_castle_complete_30cm.stl is a 30 cm tall model with two pieces in one print.
empire_sand_castle_part1of2_30cm.stl and empire_sand_castle_part2of2_30cm.stl is a 30 cm tall model and both can be printed to create a larger sand castle by stacking the molds one on top of the other.

Print out the stl file.
Fill with sand.
And have fun.

description.text:
Video posted at: https://youtu.be/TqG-xDmUAEc

Remember catching fireflys as a child and watching them in awe as they lit up at random in your hands? Now you can recreate that experience with 3d printed fireflys.

Uses an arduino micro, 12 LEDs, and 3d printed parts

If you make this, fireflys should print well on their backs with a raft without supports.

Updated 26 JUL with Jar insert that fits 9V battery and also attached the Arduino program I used for it with pin instructions.

Tools Needed:

  • Arduino Software
  • Soldering Iron/Solder
  • Breadboard
  • Glue gun/glue
  • Wire clippers/strippers
  • Dremel tool (to cut circuit board to fit insert)
  • Drill

Parts to Buy:
-12 x yellow LED's

  • toggle switch
  • arduino micro
  • thin wire
  • 12 x 220ohm resistors
  • 1x 9V battery (I used a 12V 23A, but the battery did not last long, 9V should be used but you'll need to stretch out the jar insert slightly to make it taller)
  • circuit board
  • large mason/kerr jar (7 in tall) with narrow mouth.

1) Print out:
a- Number of fireflys you want. I used 12.
b- The 9V Mason Jar insert.

2) Write arduino code to light up the LED's randomly. I used a delay of 1 to 15 seconds on each LED, completely independent of each other - no patterns makes it mesmerizing to look at. The program I used is attached as a source file, feel free to use it.

3) Start putting together the LEDs. The leds should go from one of the pins listed in the program to ground with a resistor somewhere along the current path (either side of the LED). The long end of the LED should the positive voltage side. Test the arduino and LEDs on a breadboard to make sure it works as you want it to before soldering it.

4) Trim LED leads to little 1/4" stubs, solder the LED stubs to the wires, and carefully string through the fireflys. Then fix with hotglue. At this point, I put a piece of blue tape on each of the positive sides of the LEDs so I knew which wire to solder. (or you could use different color wires)

5) Plan out the circuit board to fit into the inside of the printed jar insert. Solder LED wires to the board and test each LED separately to make sure you didn't break a wire putting it in place. Fit the board and battery into the jar insert and see where you need to trim. At this point, you may need a dremel tool to cut the circuit board to fit.

6) Solder the arduino to the board, and power it up with USB to make sure you put it in right (I soldered it in backwards the first time - don't make the same mistake)

7) Solder/wire in the toggle switch and battery and fit into insert. Drill hole in mason jar lid to fit in the switch.

8) Bend the wires of the fireflys so they appear spread out throughout the jar. Turn out the lights and enjoy.

description.text:
This is part of filament_watch, which pauses or stops OctoPrint if the filament jams or runs out during a 3D print. Code and setup instructions at https://github.com/rllynch/filament_watch.

These STLs hold a "Signswise 600p/r Incremental Rotary Encoder" from Amazon. The encoder measures the filament being consumed by the printer. If the actual filament consumed is significantly less than the filament specified by the gcode (e.g. jam or clog), the print is cancelled.

description.text:
Case to suit a Raspberry Pi2 or B2. Specifically designed to house a Kodi media player that I built, but could be used as a general purpose Raspberry Pi housing.

Variants:
Kodi_Box: A square enclosure with the Kodi symbol on top and space for a second PCB

Kodi_Box_small: A smaller version of the Kodi box without the PCB space

Picase_small: The smaller Kodi box but without the logo. Bert Haverkamp has made a bottom that fits this case and the small kodi box that has some mounting slots (Pibox-bottom_small_mountholes)

Pibox_SD: The smaller Picase with a slot so that the SD card can be removed without removing the top. The box is slightly shorter than the Picase, so the bottoms are not interchangeable between the two.

Pibox_WM: A wall mount version of Pibox_SD.

Pibox_large: The larger box with a slot for the SD card and without the Kodi logo.

Notes:

  • All tops have a NOSUP variant that is intended to be printed without support material. They have blanking plates in the holes that can be cut out.
  • The bottom for the small picase also fits the small kodi box.

OK, OK, I'll admit it. I cheated.

The surface finish is the result of using several coats of auto body filler, wet and dry sandpaper and acrylic lacquer, not vapour smoothing.

Just print it out (no need for support, it's built into the model - I'll get to why in a minute). You may need to sand down the edges of the bottom cover to get it to slide in without it getting stuck. Apart from a Raspberry PI (duh!), you will need 5 x #4 countersunk screws about 10mm long to secure the bottom cover, and you should drill out the screw holes to 2.5mm because they will more than likely have printed undersize.

The holes for the HDMI and USB ports will probably need to be trimmed a little so that they don't put any pressure on the connectors when the raspberry pi is installed. Obviously, you should remove the support plugs from these holes, although you can leave the ethernet and USB ports covered up if you want to.

You will notice the extra space and the rectangular window on the opposite side from the HDMI and USB port holes. That 's for an add-on circuit board to go into. The spacing of the support posts is a multiple of 0.1", so they line up with the holes in a piece of veroboard (or any other prototyping board with 0.1" hole spacing, which is most of them).

There is no need for screws to mount the veroboard - it sits on the posts, and the bottom cover holds it in place. Open the relevant holes in the veroboard out to 3mm and they should just slide neatly onto the mounting posts. If not, you may need to trim the posts a little.

In the case of the Kodi box project that I designed it for, the rectangular hole is for a red acrylic window to go into because there is an IR receiver behind it.

I built the support into the model to give the option to have the window there or not. If you don't need a window, just fill the gaps with some sort of filler - or just leave it. If you want a window, just cut out the filler plate.

More detailed assembly instructions can be found on instructables: http://www.instructables.com/id/Raspberry-pi-Kodi-network-media-player-for-less-th/

ADDENDUM:
Following a request from Bert Haverkamp (I think?), I have added some smaller versions of the box that are more suited to use as a general purpose Raspberry Pi enclosure. They are:

Kodi_box_top: A smaller Kodi box without the space for the add-on board and without the IR window.

Kodi_box_top_nosup: The small Kodi box with infill so it can be printed without support. The infill also serves as a blanking plate to cover the holes if you don't want them.

Picase_top: Similar to the smaller Kodi box, but without the logo.

Picase_top_nosup: As for the Kodi box, this can be printed without support.

Picase_bottom: Case bottom to suit both the picase and the small Kodi case, I've designed it with a 0.5mm gap all the way around to allow for any printing inaccuracies. As with the full sized Kodi box, it's held on with 4 x #4 countersunk wood screws.

description.text:
This is an alternative to the Leatherman Tread

I designed this with easy printing in mind. All the links can be printed with no overhang. If the buckle proves to be too difficult to print, you can add extra links so that the bracelet can slide over your wrist

First, print a link to check the scaling and ensure the hex bits fir snug, if not, it would be better to print one instead of a plate full.

Rescale as nessecary

Print ~20 links, and both parts of the buckle if desired.

I used M3 machine screws with a threaded shaft 14mm long. Anything longer can be trimmed down if desired.

description.text:
Lampe Mecapsuleur à LED qui s'allume avec une clée .

Les branchements sont fait avec de la récupération (cosses pour l' interrupteur ).

Le Mécapsuleur a été agrandi avant tranchage : X , Y = 1.25 / Z = 1 .

Le pied en forme de shaker peut etre fait en une partie ou deux (suivant modele imprimante ) .

Le socle en forme de capsule à été fait sans support .

L'interrupteur est fait d 'un axe + un pivot .

Fonctionne avec une pile LR03 AAA 1,5v , une pile quartz LR44 AG13 et une LED .

Toutes les piéces ont été imprimées en PLA naturel .

Connections are made with recovery (terminals for the switch).

The Mécapsuleur was expanded before slicing: X, Y = 1.25 / Z = 1.

The shaker shaped foot can be done in a game or two (depending on printer model).

The capsule-shaped pedestal was done without support.

The switch is made of a + a pivot axis.

Operates with LR03 AAA battery 1.5v, a quartz battery LR44 AG13 and an LED.

All parts were printed in natural PLA.

A cap to replace your front derailleur when running a single chainring.
Print in any colour to match your bike. Makes it all look tidy!
Step 1: google Okazaki fragments.  Step 2: skip ahead to a Printrbot, and build backwards to a version 2 Prusa.  Uses mostly standard hardware.

uses 3/8" smooth rod, 5/16" threaded for the z axis, 2 inch aluminum flat stock, and 3" aluminum channel for the x-carriage,and #8-32 screws 1.25 inch long. It is also designed to use cheap bronze bearings ( http://www.use-enco.com/CGI/INSRIT?PMAKA=404-2499&PMPXNO=30822520&PARTPG=INLMK32 ), and has room for a second (mirrored) extruder. Hack away, comes with parametric openSCAD files, make a 4 inch bed version, whatever floats your boat
Special hardware: uses metric m3 bolts and nuts for the motors, small gear, and pulleys. #6-32 for the z-couplers and x-carriage tensioners. 3/8" long #8 for the tapped holes on the belt clamps. 3/8" bolts to bolt the top plate to your board/workbench, don't over tighten or the aluminium top plate will bow.

title: Range Rover number plate (license plate) screw clip

description.text:
I took the number plate off my L322 RR because it was stuck with adhesive pads and not screwed on properly. Then I found out why - the clip the screw would go into was missing. Here's the replacement.

At this size PLA isn't strong - you will probably only get once chance to snap it into position and screw into it, and you would do well to cut the thread with the screw before you put it in place.

description.text:
I bought ABB Change-over "transfer" switch for DIN-rail and the default handle was almost impossible to use.

I decided to make this handle instead of buying an original part which was a bit too expensive.

Don't use any screws or glue — it will snap into place and hold firmly without any issues.

title: Bolt Together Reinforced Snow Skiis / Blades

description.text:
Snow Skiis, segmented small enough to print on a 3D printer as small as a micro 3D. There are holes down the length of the ski which allows insertion of up to 8x threaded rods to hold the segments in place, in line, and still allow for the required flex.

The design was intended as a cheap experimental ski to test out something like knee ski's or a single ski to bring waterski type slalom to the slopes

parts labled "2&6" and "3&5" need to be printed twice as they are the inverse of eachother. just assemble them in order, glue them together if you like, or just insert 1/8 threaded rod into the holes and bolt tightly using nuts in the provisions cut out at each end.

mount some straps, bindings, whatever you like and head up the mountain.

remixed_from.author: RomanST
remixed_from.title: OBSOLETE: Geared extruder with bsp fitting for flexible filament

title: Geared bowden extruder for mk8 and flexible filament

description.text:
There are an equal amount of extruders on thingiverse as there is 3d printers in the world. And none fitted my requirements, so i made one more...

I wanted a geared extruder for MK8 and I wanted the bowden tube clamped on without bsp fittings and some chance to be able to print flexible filaments. And I also wanted to beable to test and use a woodworking clamp instead of springs. And I wanted openscad drawings for it. So I made it from scratch with some inspiration from others that have some parts I wanted. The Gears are directly from RomanST extruder and have a gear ratio of 3.54.

The extruder is also made in a way that its easy to make a direct drive version of it,

I also wanted a quick way to change the filament, this I have not really done in a way I am satisfied with yet so there will be some upgrade to make it better in that way.

The bearings used are 2x 625zz (5x16x5) for the M5 bolt and 1x 608 for the filament idler.

A 50mm+ M5 bolt, recommended to use one that is not threaded all the way where the mk8 gear is mounted.

The springs don't have to be strong with this one... you can also use a screw without spring.

The extruder_holder.stl is optional and it is placed between the extruder base plate and the nema stepper. I used flexible PLA for it to reduce noise.

comments.text: Love it. I like it because it uses the m5 bolt and you can use the stock spline instead of having to buy or make an m8 hobbed bearing. I didn't worry about using a full thread bearing, I just grinded a flat spot with my dremel so the set screw catches..  Works great!
comments.author: Mchaos

comments.text:
I've made one of these, the problem is the MK8 keeps getting loose on the M5 screw and ruins the prints. I've tighten it multiple times but it keeps getting loose.
I was using this mk8 gear on my previous extruder and didn't have this problem, so I doubt it's the gear.
comments.author: WhiteRenard

comments.text: The M5 screw is threaded all the way btw, which might be the issue... Any solution? should I try to glue it to the bolt?
comments.author: WhiteRenard

comments.text: I have used a M5 bolt that is not threaded where the mk8 is. If the grubscrew in the mk8 is long enought you can try and file a flat spot for the screw to be in. But remember that a threaded m5 is smaller than non threaded so the mk8 might get off center and cause uneven extrution.
comments.author: WhiteRenard

comments.text:
Thank you for the reply. I just glued it yesterday and it's working really well! :P
I'm gonna post a make today, thanks!
comments.author: condac

comments.text: I still use this extruder for both my machines and it works well. Some times when the nozzle clogs the bowden tube can get loose on the extruder side, and you don't want to clamp it too much because it can deform and make the inner diameter to small. But threading a nut on the bowden might help and i have made grooves for it in the part but never got time to test it yet, it doesn't come loose that often.
comments.author: WhiteRenard

comments.text: will you please upload some extra photos of the assembled extruder?
comments.author: reprapiran

comments.text: Do you have a full parts list?
comments.author: carbon8

comments.text: Did you test it with TPE / Ninjaflex / Rubber? How much clearance is between the body and the gear?
comments.author: RomanST

comments.text: I have tested with flexible FPE, and it managed about 20mm/s before it escaped between 608 and the inlet. I have closed the gap a it more in that area with the latest version (beta4). The clearance between 608, mk8 and the inlet is 0mm in cad and the printed part flexes and missaligns a bit so there is a <1mm gap as end result. But I have been very annoyed by extruders where the 608 bearing hit plastic before it get tension on the filament so I have left a bit more space.
comments.author: RomanST

comments.text: 608 bearing? i though tthis used 625?
comments.author: condac

comments.text: The bearings for the 5mm bolt are 625, the bearing for the filament is 608

author: dewme5

description.text:
Yarn Ball Winder.
https://youtu.be/ouDcB0rApS0

Once everything is printed press the bearings into place. The small pulley takes two bearing. The trick about the 1/4" O'Ring to connect the ends of the O'Ring together is to melt them slightly and press them together until they are cooled off. Or use O'Ring super glue. Be sure when using the winder to wind in a clockwise rotation or the cone will come unscrewed.
Once everything is put together. Adjust the pulley that rides on the cone it will have to make 100% contact around the cone. Then tighten the bolt. This will cause the small pulley to rotate around it's own axis as it spins around the cone.
Turn in a CW motion, If you turn the large pulley CCW it will unscrew the cone.

title: LED poi, powered by 2xAAA batteries! Spinny lights! Light up the night!

description.text:
First of all, WATCH THIS VIDEO: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=76OVStXA5N0 THIS explains poi!

This is the best design I've come up with so far! Want to talk about lighting up the night? There is NOTHING like spinning poi to do that! Originally a tradition by Pacific Islanders using things on fire, this is much safer!

These were printed in glow-in-the-dark Hatchbox PLA. I can turn them on for a little bit, then turn them back off, and keep spinning! The batteries for these will last ages and ages! My calculations show between 75 and 100 hours on a single set of AAA batteries!

I first tried to take a video in the dark at the park down the street from me, and drew an audience. These are great!

The reason this is a winner? It's so simple, and so easy, yet it lights up the night better than anything I've seen on here!

The rules specifically say: "Make a 3D-printable design that incorporates LED lights, for wearing, using, or watching during those warm summer nights" - and there's no invention on here that lights up the night better than this!!!

This is the 3rd and most decent version of LED poi that I've designed and printed so far. There is a much smaller version with a single LED on my channel, but that has the LED facing outwards.

This version uses the rope to hold in the battery compartment. It's very secure once the rope is tied off.

I also designed one with nine LEDs, all of which poke through a poi ball. This actually didn't work well. it's just harsh on the eyes.

So, this design uses a single LED, that's pointed at plastic from the other side. it works much better - watch the video if you don't believe me!

While my design used a battery box with a switch from Ebay, which is very cheap, I have also included a box that you can wire the LED to then super glue to the same supports I created. Just need to use a paper clip through the hole for your wiring.

Required for the build is a single LED, some rope (I used glow-in-the-dark Harbor Freight rope), any soldering iron (this process is so easy, anyone can do it), some super glue, two batteries, the correct wiring, and an optional battery box with switch.

I'll be including a wiring diagram and a picture of the wiring for an RGB LED with a 3-position switch. This is only a few additional dollars, and you can have 3 different colors, instead of just a single one! Just have to glue the switch in place, too, then you have 3 colors!

Actual cost of (faaaar extra) materials for me, in the US:
-100x white LEDs on Ebay: $1.31, free shipping
-100x UV LEDs (black lights) on Ebay: $3.29 shipped
-100x RGB diffused LEDs, common anode: $7.77 shipped
-3-way switch for RGB LEDs: 10x for $2
-AAA battery boxes with switches and wires: $0.77 /each
-Harbor Freight 1/4" glow in the dark rope: $4

You can literally build the same thing I did by ordering some rope form Harbor Freight and ordering a few LEDs and a battery box with switch for under $10 for the pair. Using RGB LEDs, you'll still be under $15 for the pair if you bought too many components.

My next design will involve an ATTiny85 microchip. Unfortunately, these didn't arrive in time for me to use them in this contest. Using these, I can get all sorts of RGB patterns, blinks, and color changes.

This one, though, is perfect in its simplicity! Get printed, and get spinning! :D

comments.text:
I am a designer of Neopixel poi, and I DID NOT STEAL YOUR IDEA!
My design (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:943343) is so obviously different, I won't even start to describe how different it is. Both of us put a lot of work and time in to our designs, just because mine came out a few days after yours does not mean that I copied it.
The idea of putting LED(s) on poi is not at all unique, as can be proven by a quick Internet search. However no 2 slightly different designs are "the exact same thing" as you claim our two designs to be.

title: Digital Micrometer fast-clamp mounting for k8200/3drag.

description.text:
This frame mounting is for a micrometer used to verify the plate and
the z-zero switch in the original k8200/3drag.

This thing uses modules defined in the library fast-clamp05.scad, so it is easy to design and to use. You don't need any tool to place and remove the micrometer.

For more infos see also fast-clamp05 library: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:936871

Complete collection of Add-on for 3Drag/K8200 using Fast Clamp: http://www.thingiverse.com/sillano/collections/3drag-fast-clamp-addon

Instructions (stl file)

  • print all 3 parts
    (tested using PLA, layer 0.2, perimeter 6 layers, infill 80%-100%,
    requires supports)
  • use a M4 bolt and self-locking nut to tie the noose and link parts.
    Attention to parts position.
  • use a M4 bolt and washer and nut to place the micrometer.

Modifications (scad file)
To use the micrometer.scad file, you also need the library fast-clamp05.scad added here for your convenience.

extra:

  • Digital micrometer (ebay) diam. 8 mm.
  • 1 x M4 bolt 35 mm long and self-locking M4 nut (for clip)
  • 1 x M4 bolt 20 mm long and M4 nut and M4 washer (for micrometer)

author: TrickyKid

title: Parametric fast-clamp OpenSCAD library for K8200/3Drag

description.text:
This OpenSCAD library generates a K8200/3Drag frame mounting clamp with locking.
I designed this fast-clamp library to make stong mounts for all type of accessories: extruders, drill, laser, fan, cam... and more.
The accessories change is easy and fast as it does not require any tool.
As bonus you can add holes for standard fixing, using M5 screws and squared nuts.

A photo shows my first thing I made using this library: a digital micrometer to adjust the printing plate http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:936831. Complete collection of Add-on for 3Drag/K8200 using Fast Clamp: here: http://www.thingiverse.com/sillano/collections/3drag-fast-clamp-addon

2 main modules are defined:
a) clip(height, holes, h_pos), to be used in custom mount design for your device.
b) click(height), 2 parts to fix the clip.

See pics to find how to assemble the fast-clamp.

This design is experimental and may change, but usable as is.
Thanks to makers:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:424674 for a simple clamp
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:444323 for the alu profile.

The STL file is for a test clamp, height 10 mm.

ver. 0.6.0 29/11/2015 click strengthened.
ver. 0.5.1 23/07/2015 added lower and upper limits to adjust_link.
ver. 0.5.0 16/07/2015 base version.

How to use "fast-clamp.scad" library:

  • put the file in the same directory as your project.
  • add on top of your OpenSCAD code: "use ;"
  • then you can use the modules clip() and click() as you like.
    Example:
    "clip(18, 0);
    click(18);"

How to get the sample fast-clamp alone (fast-clamp05.stl):

  • print all 3 parts
    (tested using PLA, layer 0.2, perimeter 6 layers, infill 80%-100%)

  • use a M4 screw and nut to tie the noose and link parts.
    Attention to parts position: use F5 to see the fast-clamp assembled.

    extra:
    screw M4, long height+15 mm and self-locking nut

note:
In case of large clamps it can be useful to mofify the library products in 2 ways:
1) make the clamp more elastic
2) make the click strengthened (done: see fast-clamp06)

I do that in http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:951383 (see it as example), for now i think not necessary to change this in the main library.

title: Prusa i3 Direct Extruder with Inductive mount

description.text:
Designed to hold the direct extruder and an induction sensor for my prusa i3.

Made in onshape.com

Versions:
Extruder, This is the generic version, shims/spacers will be needed on the motor to make the hole line up, the hole is for 1.75mm filament

ExtruderV2, This has been modified for http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/3D-Printer-Filament-Feeder-Extruder-Feed-Upgrade-Fit-Nema-17-Motor-RepRap-/191449385041 without the need for shims, the hole is again for 1.75mm filament

Clamp is compatible with both versions

If there any any requests for I will do a 3mm version.

Once I have it printed and running I will make a fan mount for it, the back of the clamp screws will be the mounting point.

Thanks for looking.

Print one extruder and one clamp,
(I'm going to print the part studio as one piece to see if that will work, I will report back UPDATE: Yes it printed fine as one piece.)

If you printed the original version then space out the motor with washers or spacers so that the hole from your direct feeder lines up with the centre of the hot end.

Update: Uploaded a new version of the gemma and NeoPixel 12 ring middle section with screw holes that line up with the 18350 battery holder. September 20, 2016

*Update: Found some time to create a battery holder for an 18350 battery. It works great and uses two screws to hold it onto the middle section or can be glued on. It fits the taller mushroom base. I just uploaded it and I'll upload new middle parts soon with holes for the battery holder screws. September 19, 2016

Added another middle section version that can be used with an adafruit gemma board and a 12 x RGB LED NeoPixel Ring: July 26, 2015

Added an alternate middle section that is more open. Larger mini arduinos can be placed in it. Such as the Microduino and Adafruit Gemma: July 24, 2015

Now there is a stars top for the mushroom light :) and added a third bottom section: July 24, 2015

I just added a more rounded top. I might make a couple more tops for this mushroom light.

Updated dimensions for middle part. Should fit better: July 23, 2015

Updated base to be more round towards the bottom: July 22, 2015

I made this mushroom light for the #LightItUp challenge since I love objects that resemble mushrooms. It uses a cheap and simple Digispark pro arduino. It can be programmed to be a mood light or it can be used without the top as a white flashlight. The base houses three 18350 lithium batteries. I kept the design simple so that it would be easy to modify and when printed, it should be easy to hold as a flashlight if needed. The main purpose is colorful ambient lighting but can be used for useful white light. I am currently printing out my design to see if everything fits. Might need a little bit of sanding.

https://youtu.be/esfTOk8Hzk8
https://youtu.be/qRp8MbFy3EA
https://youtu.be/qxC_voGPbQ8
https://youtu.be/tGGcf7lQ1tI

Update: The battery holder that I just uploaded uses solderable battery clips and small screws that are no wider than 3mm.

I forgot to add space for the battery terminal and cable on the gemma middle section STL file. I added an opening creating space for the cabling so that no sanding or cutting are required. It's the file that says updated on the end.

There are three middle sections now. One hollowed out that can fit many mini sized microcontroller boards 36mm or less, one that fits the digispark pro, which has the rectangular hole, and one that will fit the adafruit gemma and 12 x RGB NeoPixel ring. The NeoPixel ring can be stuck to the top ring of the middle section, and the gemma board can be placed in the bottom inside part of the middle section.

FYI: I've been printing the mushroom parts at 0.2mm layer height, 30% infill, standard thickness shell, and slow speed on my xyzprinting da vinci junior PLA printer. The parts have come out very well. Not perfectly circular, but still pretty good.

I found a thingm blinkm that I had lying around and am using that for the light source. It's a nice standalone programmable rgb led light. It can be programmed with a Linkm and then only requires a 5v source. I used a RCR123A LiFePO4 battery connected to a dc-dc 5v power supply to drive it. Works great!

I designed the mushroom base to house three 18350 batteries which are easy to find online, since they are used by many Vape devices. I'll be using magnets to connect them, but later on I'll make a better battery setup. The middle piece is where the digispark pro goes and there is a hole in the center for the battery wires. The batteries can be connected in series since the digispark has a voltage regulator. I'm using the digispark led shield with it, but any led that doesn't overpower the digispark can be used. The digispark can output 500ma. My current design does not have any screw down places so I'll be using double sided tape. The base, middle section, and top are currently designed to be pushed together. I wanted the top to be easily removable so that it can be used as a white light flashlight to look around in the dark.

title: Simple E3D hotend holder for B.I v2.5

description.text:
Monted in the middle of the effector, this will hold a E3D hotend. This model is made for the v5 hotend (25mm diameter) but the v6 should also work.

the fan holder is molded is the bottom plate so it wont move/wobble while printing

ABS (or high temp material) should be used to print this thing as theres alot of heat around it.

1. insert the top plate on the hotend
  2. screw in the holder around the hotend's neck with (2x) M3x30mm
  3. screw the holder onto the top plate using the 2 back holes (2x) M3x20mm
  4. insert the bottom plate while inserting the wires.
  5. screw the top & bottom plate together with (2x) M3x25mm in front and (1x) M3x16mm in the back.

Fan is a 30x30x10 12V. You will need a constant 12V line from the board to the hotend.. some extra wire are available on the Z-axis tower.
You can use M3x14mm to install the fan.. I use only 2/4 holes. that scrong enough.

title: Safety Bumper for Jabra UC550 Headset Control

description.text:
The Jabra UC550 is a fantastic telephone headset but the control fob is designed so far down the wire that it sits/ drags on the table, its protruding buttons waiting in ambush for you to un-mute yourself at the worst of times.

This safety bumper prevents that while allowing full access to the buttons - when you want to. The flat base will let you attach the fob to a tie clip, desk, laptop etc with tape, velcro, a magnet.

Don't want to risk touching the buttons while on an important call? Rest the whole thing upside down on a flat surface.

No more conference call miscues!

comments.text: YES! Brilliant idea. I always mute myself with this otherwise find headset.

I want a MakerBot, and I've got a ShopBot (that we've done a lot with - http://becausewecan.org). So I took the Makerbot laser-cut chassis file, and tried to make it into something a CNC router can cut out. This is a first pass at this, I haven't gotten to cutting it just yet as two or three parts are looking rather fragile and I need to look at some build pics to see if that's going to be a problem or not! If you beat me to cutting one out (which is likely!) then I'd love to hear how it goes.

The file is setup to be cut out entirely with a 1/8" bit. Once I get a 'final' that I know works, I'll post up a nested and non-nested file for cutting.
It looks like from simple nesting that the Makerbot takes up about a third of a sheet of standard plywood. You might be able to get four out of a single sheet, and it looks like it might take a half hour at most to cut out per chassis.

description.text:
Vivienda unifamiliar (Proyecto y obra de 2006) a escala 1:100. Los ficheros STL están a esa escala, aunque yo los he reducido un 10% al imprimir en mi prusa I3 Hephestos.
Tiene algunos fallos de concepto, fruto de la inexperiencia, pero para la próxima maqueta ya se que nivel de detalle merece la pena a ese tamaño.
Los cristales no se me han impreso, imagino que por delgadez (en la planta alta ya no los puse por ello), pero creo que queda mejor así.
He colocado unos soportes para retirar en las ventanas en esquina de la planta alta.
Los muebles los he impreso en otro color para dar contraste.
Creo que el resultado no es malo y me ha servido para ver las posibilidades de aplicación a mi profesión (la arquitectura) de la impresión 3D.

El modelo lo he impreso algo mas pequeño, por miedo a ocupar mucha superficie de plato, pero cabe perfectamente en la bandeja de la Prusa I3.
Está impreso en PLA a 0.3, 65 mm/s y 205ºC.
Hay un par de soportes a retirar en las ventanas de esquina de arriba (por el voladizo).
En la planta baja, hay unos conectores que hay que quitar (en un principio quería conectar las plantas pero no funcionaba. Se quita facil con un cuter.
Para encajar la planta baja y la alta he tenido que lijar un pelín el ultimo escalón del tiro, ya que rozaba algo por los laterales.
Las barandillas son muy delicadas, a mi la de la planta baja me ha dado problemas y la he quitado. Todo dependerá de como tengais la impresora de bien calibrada y controlada.

This is a 1:40 model of the Morgantown PRT.

This system opened in the 1970's and was built by Boeing. It is the only system of its kind in the world. It transports students at West Virginia University between 5 different stations. The unique feature of this system is the offline nature of the stations - vehicles can travel directly from origin to destination, with no intermediate stops. Technically classified as "Group Rapid Transit", it continues to run to this day for just 50 cents per ride, or free to students.

Photo of the actual system is from Wikipedia.

Print each of the STL files. They can all be printed with no support.

Glue the windows into the sockets of the vehicle body.

Glue the guide wheel bars to the chassis bar, and glue the wheels onto the chassis (they are a press fit, so glue actually isn't required).

Press 5 x 16mm dowel pins into the bottom of the vehicle body and it will snap onto the chassis.

comments.text: This is awesome!  I'm a WVU grad and made a foamboard PRT cover for a model train to go around our WV themed Christmas tree.  I've been wanting to design and print one instead and this will be a great starting point for integrating model train parts.  Next Christmas this will be going around my tree!  :)
